title: How to Open WordPad in Windows 10

steps.headline: Click the search bar/icon on the taskbar.
steps.description:
If it's missing, then click on the Start {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/0\/07\/Windowsstart.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/0\/07\/Windowsstart.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":460,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":760,"licensing":"

\n<\/p><\/div>"} button.

steps.headline: Hit the ↵ Enter key or select the matching result.

methods.name: Accessing through "All Apps" List in the Start Menu

steps.headline:
Click on the Start {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/0\/07\/Windowsstart.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/0\/07\/Windowsstart.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":460,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":760,"licensing":"

\n<\/p><\/div>"} button.
Open the All apps list from the left of the Start menu.
steps.description: You can also scroll if you've configured it to show on the tiles page.

steps.headline: Press the ⊞ Win+R keyboard keys at the same time.
Type write, wordpad, or %SystemDrive%/Program Files/Windows NT/Accessories/WordPad.exe.
Hit the ↵ Enter key or click OK.
Open File Explorer.
steps.description:
You can do this quickly by clicking the taskbar icon {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/b\/b1\/WindowsFileExplorer.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/b\/b1\/WindowsFileExplorer.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":460,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":760,"licensing":"

I edited this screenshot of a Windows icon.\n<\/p>

License: Fair Use<\/a>
\n<\/p><\/div>"} or pressing ⊞ Win+E.

steps.headline: Type %SystemDrive%/Program Files/Windows NT/Accessories.
steps.description: Hit ↵ Enter or click the right arrow →. You can also manually navigate to the folder, replacing "%SystemDrive%" with your drive letter (usually C:).

steps.headline: Open the "wordpad" executable file.
steps.description: It might have ".exe" at the end of the name depending on your file viewing settings.

steps.headline: Open the Command Prompt.
steps.description:
One way is to right-click the Start {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/0\/07\/Windowsstart.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/0\/07\/Windowsstart.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":460,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":760,"licensing":"

I edited this screenshot of a Windows icon.\n<\/p>

License: Public Domain<\/a>
\n<\/p><\/div>"} button and click Command Prompt.

steps.headline: Run Powershell.
steps.description:
Type powershell into the taskbar search bar (or launch the Start {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/0\/07\/Windowsstart.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/0\/07\/Windowsstart.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":460,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":760,"licensing":"

I edited this screenshot of a Windows icon.\n<\/p>

License: Public Domain<\/a>
\n<\/p><\/div>"} menu and type if the bar is missing).

steps.headline: Select "Windows PowerShell".
steps.description: Ignore any advanced results that may appear (such as "PowerShell ISE" and "PowerShell (x86)").

steps.headline: Wait until you see the Microsoft copyright info at the top.
steps.description: Depending on your computer, there might be a delay of up to 5 seconds until this appears.

text:
Using Windows Search Click the search bar/icon on the taskbar. If it's missing, then click on the Start {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/0/07/Windowsstart.png","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/0/07/Windowsstart.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":460,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":760,"licensing":"

I edited this screenshot of a Windows icon.

License: Public Domain

"} button. Type wordpad. Hit the ↵ Enter key or select the matching result. Accessing through "All Apps" List in the Start Menu Click on the Start {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/0/07/Windowsstart.png","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/0/07/Windowsstart.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":460,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":760,"licensing":"

I edited this screenshot of a Windows icon.

License: Public Domain

"} button. Open the All apps list from the left of the Start menu. You can also scroll if you've configured it to show on the tiles page. Click the "Windows Accessories" folder. Choose "WordPad". Running through the Dialog Window Press the ⊞ Win+R keyboard keys at the same time. Type write, wordpad, or %SystemDrive%/Program Files/Windows NT/Accessories/WordPad.exe. Hit the ↵ Enter key or click OK. Searching with File Explorer Open File Explorer. You can do this quickly by clicking the taskbar icon {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/b/b1/WindowsFileExplorer.png","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/b/b1/WindowsFileExplorer.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":460,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":760,"licensing":"

I edited this screenshot of a Windows icon.

License: Fair Use

"} or pressing ⊞ Win+E. Type %SystemDrive%/Program Files/Windows NT/Accessories. Hit ↵ Enter or click the right arrow →. You can also manually navigate to the folder, replacing "%SystemDrive%" with your drive letter (usually C:). Open the "wordpad" executable file. It might have ".exe" at the end of the name depending on your file viewing settings. Using the Command Prompt Open the Command Prompt. One way is to right-click the Start {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/0/07/Windowsstart.png","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/0/07/Windowsstart.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":460,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":760,"licensing":"

I edited this screenshot of a Windows icon.

License: Public Domain

"} button and click Command Prompt. Type write or wordpad.exe. Hit ↵ Enter. Opening with Windows PowerShell Run Powershell. Type powershell into the taskbar search bar (or launch the Start {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/0/07/Windowsstart.png","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/0/07/Windowsstart.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":460,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":760,"licensing":"

I edited this screenshot of a Windows icon.

License: Public Domain

"} menu and type if the bar is missing). Select "Windows PowerShell". Ignore any advanced results that may appear (such as "PowerShell ISE" and "PowerShell (x86)"). Wait until you see the Microsoft copyright info at the top. Depending on your computer, there might be a delay of up to 5 seconds until this appears. Type write.exe. Hit ↵ Enter.
sentences: Using Windows Search Click the search bar/icon on the taskbar.

If it's missing, then click on the Start {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/0\/07\/Windowsstart.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/0\/07\/Windowsstart.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":460,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":760,"licensing":"

Type wordpad.
Hit the ↵ Enter key or select the matching result.

Accessing through "All Apps" List in the Start Menu Click on the Start {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/0\/07\/Windowsstart.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/0\/07\/Windowsstart.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":460,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":760,"licensing":"

License: Public Domain<\/a>
\n<\/p><\/div>"} button.
Open the All apps list from the left of the Start menu.
You can also scroll if you've configured it to show on the tiles page.
Click the "Windows Accessories" folder.
Choose "WordPad".
Running through the Dialog Window Press the ⊞ Win+R keyboard keys at the same time.
Type write, wordpad, or %SystemDrive%/Program Files/Windows NT/Accessories/WordPad.exe.
Hit the ↵ Enter key or click OK.  Searching with File Explorer Open File Explorer.

You can do this quickly by clicking the taskbar icon {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/b\/b1\/WindowsFileExplorer.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/b\/b1\/WindowsFileExplorer.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":460,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":760,"licensing":"

I edited this screenshot of a Windows icon.\n<\/p>

License: Fair Use<\/a>
\n<\/p><\/div>"} or pressing ⊞ Win+E.
Type %SystemDrive%/Program Files/Windows NT/Accessories.
Hit ↵ Enter or click the right arrow →.
You can also manually navigate to the folder, replacing "%SystemDrive%" with your drive letter (usually C:).
Open the "wordpad" executable file.
It might have ".exe" at the end of the name depending on your file viewing settings.
Using the Command Prompt Open the Command Prompt.

One way is to right-click the Start {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/0\/07\/Windowsstart.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/0\/07\/Windowsstart.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":460,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":760,"licensing":"

I edited this screenshot of a Windows icon.\n<\/p>

License: Public Domain<\/a>
\n<\/p><\/div>"} button and click Command Prompt.
Type write or wordpad.exe.
Hit ↵ Enter.
Opening with Windows PowerShell Run Powershell.

Type powershell into the taskbar search bar (or launch the Start {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/0\/07\/Windowsstart.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/0\/07\/Windowsstart.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":460,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":760,"licensing":"

I edited this screenshot of a Windows icon.\n<\/p>

License: Public Domain<\/a>
\n<\/p><\/div>"} menu and type if the bar is missing).
Select "Windows PowerShell".
Ignore any advanced results that may appear (such as "PowerShell ISE" and "PowerShell (x86)").
Wait until you see the Microsoft copyright info at the top.
Depending on your computer, there might be a delay of up to 5 seconds until this appears.
Type write.exe.
Hit ↵ Enter.
